title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force's role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force is outlined in Section 1. The Air Force's management of the Civil Air Patrol includes administrative responsibility under the Chief of Staff of the Air Force and a National Board of Directors appointed by the Secretary of the Air Force. The Secretary of the Air Force appoints a National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol, composed of general officers, senior civilian employees, and volunteer members. The chairman is the senior active duty Air Force officer, and the Board appoints executive direction for the Civil Air Patrol. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol appoints key positions including a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. The Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign Air Force officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The appointment or assignment of these individuals is not restricted by laws prohibiting their participation in non-Federal entity management. Those appointed or assigned to management positions in the Civil Air Patrol will not receive additional compensation beyond their regular military pay. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol without additional compensation. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors may use Civil Air Patrol employees and volunteer members as needed for administration and noncombat mission support. Members and employees of the Civil Air Patrol are not considered Federal employees. Members and employees of the Civil Air Patrol are not considered Federal employees and are exempt from laws governing Federal employment. The Secretary of the Air Force can set conduct standards for them. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to specific financial requirements. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to financial requirements outlined in title 31. The powers granted to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. A clerical amendment removes a section from the table of sections.
